Over-the-Air Federated Multi-Task Learning

Haoming Ma Xiaojun Yuan Dian Fan Zhi Ding Xin Wang Jun Fang
Abstract

In this letter, we introduce over-the-air computation into the communication design of federated multi-task learning (FMTL), and propose an over-the-air federated multi-task learning (OA-FMTL) framework, where multiple learning tasks deployed on edge devices share a non-orthogonal fading channel under the coordination of an edge server (ES). Specifically, the model updates for all the tasks are transmitted and superimposed concurrently over a non-orthogonal uplink fading channel, and the model aggregations of all the tasks are reconstructed at the ES through a modified version of the turbo compressed sensing algorithm (Turbo-CS) that overcomes inter-task interference. Both convergence analysis and numerical results show that the OA-FMTL framework can significantly improve the system efficiency in terms of reducing the number of channel uses without causing substantial learning performance degradation.

Index Terms:
Federated multi-task learning, over-the-air computation, turbo compressed sensing.

I Introduction

With a massive amount of data at wireless edge devices, federated learning (FL) [1] has emerged as a popular framework for training machine learning models in a confidential and distributive manner. In general, FL requires uploading local model parameters from devices to a specific edge server (ES). Owing to massively distributed devices as well as a huge amount of model parameters, limited channel resource of uplink communication (e.g., bandwidth, time and space) poses a major bottleneck in the original FL framework. To this end, extensive research effort has recently been devoted to enhance communication-efficiency in FL. For example, the authors in [2, 3] proposed to relieve the uplink burden by sparsifying and compressing the local model updates before transmission. In [4, 5, 6], over-the-air computation was used to speed up local model aggregation by exploiting radio superposition over shared physical channels.

Based on the basic idea of multi-task learning [7] and FL, the authors in [8, 9] proposed the federated multi-task learning (FMTL) framework to implement multiple machine learning tasks over the FL network, so that the knowledge contained in a task can be leveraged by other tasks with the hope of improving the generalization performance [7]. Despite the appealing aspects of FMTL, the inter-task interference inherent in FMTL hinders the direct implementation of existing transmission protocols [2, 3, 4, 5, 6] designed for FL over wireless networks. To overcome the inter-task interference, a straightforward extension involves separating the uplink transmission for multi-task updates over orthogonal frequency/time sub-channels. However, this frequency/time division approach may be inefficient since the overall channel resource is divided into orthogonal ones to avoid the inter-task interference. By contrary, in this paper, we propose a novel non-orthogonal transmission scheme in the presence of inter-task interference, where the local updates for all the tasks are sent simultaneously over the same fading channel to achieve communication-efficient FMTL.

To be more specific, we investigate the over-the-air FMTL (OA-FMTL) transmission scheme, where multiple tasks deployed on edge devices share a non-orthogonal fading channel under the coordination of an ES. At every edge device, the local model updates of all tasks deployed on devices are first sparsified and compressed individually by following the approach of [2, 3], prior to being transmitted and aggregated over the uplink channel. Model aggregations of the individual tasks are reconstructed efficiently at the ES by exploiting a novel modified version of the turbo compressed sensing (Turbo-CS) algorithm [10]. State evolution and convergence analysis are established to characterize the behavior of the proposed OA-FMTL scheme. Experimental simulations show that our proposed OA-FMTL is able to achieve a learning performance comparable to the signal-task transmission scheme [4, 5] by efficiently suppressing the inter-task interference. In other words, the communication resource required by OA-FMTL is only one N-th of the conventional frequency/time division approach, where N is the total number of tasks.

II-B Over-the-Air Channel Model

We now describe the wireless channels used to support the above FMTL process. Following the convention in [4, 5, 6], we assume that the downlink transmission from the ES to the devices is error-free, and focus on the uplink. We model the wireless uplink as a block fading channel with the channel state information unchanged within each communication round. Noting that the update in (5) depends exclusively on the weighted sum of the local gradients, we employ the over-the-air computation to reduce the usage of channel resources. Specifically, at the t𝑡t-th communication round, in an analog fashion, every device equipped with an individual antenna synchronously sends its channel input vector to the ES over a block fading channel with s𝑠s frequency/time channel uses (with s≤d𝑠𝑑s\leq d), characterized by:

𝒓(t)=∑m=1Mhm(t)​𝒔m(t)+𝒘,superscript𝒓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡𝒘\bm{r}^{(t)}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}h_{m}^{(t)}\bm{s}_{m}^{(t)}+\bm{w}, (6)

where 𝒔m(t)∈ℂssuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡superscriptℂ𝑠\bm{s}_{m}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C}^{s} is the channel input vector from device m𝑚m, with the details specified later in Section III, hm(t)∈ℂsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡ℂh_{m}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C} is the channel gain from device m𝑚m to the ES, 𝒓(t)∈ℂssuperscript𝒓𝑡superscriptℂ𝑠\bm{r}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C}^{s} is the channel output received by the ES, and 𝒘∈ℂs𝒘superscriptℂ𝑠\bm{w}\in\mathbb{C}^{s} is an independent additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) with each element independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) as 𝒞​𝒩​(0,σw2)𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2\mathcal{CN}(0,\sigma_{w}^{2}). During the training process, the power consumption of device m𝑚m at each round t𝑡t is constrained by

‖𝒔m(t)‖2≤P,superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡2𝑃||\bm{s}_{m}^{(t)}||^{2}\leq P, (7)

where P𝑃P is the common power budget of each device and ||⋅||||\cdot|| denotes the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} norm.

The remaining issue is to map the real vectors {𝒈n​m(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\bm{g}_{nm}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} to the complex vector 𝒔m(t)superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑚𝑡\bm{s}_{m}^{(t)} at device m𝑚m in each communication round t𝑡t, and to recover an approximate estimate of ∇nℒn​(𝜽n)subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛subscript𝜽𝑛\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{\theta}_{n}) from 𝒓(t)subscript𝒓𝑡\bm{r}_{(t)} for each task n𝑛n at the ES. As inspired by [5, 4, 10, 11], we employ analog compressed sensing and error accumulation techniques to combat the effect of channel imperfection. The details of the uplink transceiver design are presented in what follows.

III Over-the-Air Federated Multi-Task Learning Framework

III-A Transceiver Design of OA-FMTL

III-A2 Receiver Design

We now describe the receiver design of the ES. We assume that the ES knows the set ℳ(t)superscriptℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}^{(t)}, the size of dataset Kn​msubscript𝐾𝑛𝑚K_{nm} and the power coefficient γ(t)∈ℝsuperscript𝛾𝑡ℝ\gamma^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R} at each round t𝑡t, in advance of the transmission. With (11)-(15) and appropriate scaling, (6) is rewritten as

The recovery of {𝒈n(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} from 𝒚(t)superscript𝒚𝑡\bm{y}^{(t)} in (16) is a compressed sensing problem with the compression matrix [𝑨1,…,𝑨N]subscript𝑨1…subscript𝑨𝑁[\bm{A}_{1},\dots,\bm{A}_{N}] composed of N𝑁N partial DCT matrices. Since the compression matrix is partial orthogonal, we propose to follow the idea of Turbo-CS in [10] to efficiently solve the compressed sensing problem. As each 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)} is the gradient for a different task n𝑛n, {𝒈n(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} generally have different prior distributions. We assume that the entries of 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)} are independently drawn from a Bernoulli Gaussian distribution:

gn,k(t)∼{0, probability =1−λn(t),𝒩​(0,vn(t)), probability =λn(t),similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑘𝑡cases0 probability 1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝑡 probability superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡g_{n,k}^{(t)}\sim\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0,&\text{ probability }=1-\lambda_{n}^{(t)},\\ \mathcal{N}\left(0,v_{n}^{(t)}\right),&\text{ probability }=\lambda_{n}^{(t)},\end{array}\right. (18)

where gn,k(t)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑘𝑡g_{n,k}^{(t)} is the k𝑘k-th element of 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}, λn(t)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡\lambda_{n}^{(t)} is the sparsity of 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}, and vn(t)superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝑡v_{n}^{(t)} is the variance of the nonzero elements in 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}. The above parameters in the prior distribution is estimated by the Expectation-Maximization algorithm [13]. With the above prior model, we modify the Turbo-CS algorithm accordingly to accommodate the concurrent model aggregation of the N𝑁N tasks as follows.

As shown in Fig. 2, modified Turbo-CS (M-Turbo-CS) iterates between two modules where module A handles the linear constraint in (16), and module B denoises the output from module A by exploiting the gradient sparsity in (18). Besides, the iterative process of M-Turbo-CS is carried out at every round t𝑡t and we drop out the round index t𝑡t in the following for brevity. Compared with the original Turbo-CS algorithm in [10], the main difference is that each subvector 𝒈nsubscript𝒈𝑛\bm{g}_{n} in (16) has its individual prior distribution as in (18). The above process is summarized in Algorithm 1.

III-B Performance Analysis of M-Turbo-CS

Similarly to [10], we track the state of each 𝒈nsubscript𝒈𝑛\bm{g}_{n} with its individual MSE. Combining (19b), (20b), (22b) and (23b), the state evolution of M-Turbo-CS is given by

vB,np​r​i=dns​(∑k=1NvA,kp​r​i+σ2)−vA,np​r​i,∀n∈[N],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝐵𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖subscript𝑑𝑛𝑠matrixsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑣𝐴𝑘𝑝𝑟𝑖superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑣𝐴𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁v_{B,n}^{pri}=\frac{d_{n}}{s}\begin{pmatrix}\sum_{k=1}^{N}v_{A,k}^{pri}+\sigma^{2}\end{pmatrix}-v_{A,n}^{pri},\forall n\in[N], (24a)
1vA,np​r​i=1m​m​s​en​(1/vB,np​r​i)−1vB,np​r​i,∀n∈[N],formulae-sequence1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝐴𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖1𝑚𝑚𝑠subscript𝑒𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝐵𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝐵𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\frac{1}{v_{A,n}^{pri}}=\frac{1}{mmse_{n}(1/v_{B,n}^{pri})}-\frac{1}{v_{B,n}^{pri}},\forall n\in[N], (24b)

with mmsen(1/vB,np​r​i)≡𝔼[|𝒈n−𝔼[𝒈n∣𝒈n+𝒏n]|2].mmse_{n}(1/v_{B,n}^{pri})\equiv\mathbb{E}\left[|\bm{g}_{n}-\mathbb{E}[\bm{g}_{n}\mid\bm{g}_{n}+\bm{n}_{n}]|^{2}\right]. The fixed point of (24), denoted by {vn⋆}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\star}\}_{n=1}^{N}, tracks the normalized output MSEs of the M-Turbo-CS algorithm, where vn⋆superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆v_{n}^{\star} is the fixed-point MSE of 𝒈nsubscript𝒈𝑛\bm{g}_{n} for ∀n∈Nfor-all𝑛𝑁\forall n\in N. The fixed point {vn⋆}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\star}\}_{n=1}^{N} gives an analytical characterization of the communication error after turbo recovery. This error bound will be used in the next subsection for convergence analysis of the overall OA-FMTL. Moreover, we will numerically show that the state evolution in (24) agrees well with simulation, and that M-Turbo-CS is able to efficiently suppress inter-task interference.

III-C Convergence Analysis of OA-FMTL

We now analyze the performance of the OA-FMTL framework. With (4) and (17), we analyze the bound of model updating error 𝒆(t)∈ℝdnsuperscript𝒆𝑡superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑛\bm{e}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{n}} at the t𝑡t-th round as

To proceed, following the convention in stochastic optimization [14] to ensure an upper bound on the loss ℒn​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) for each task n𝑛n, we make some assumptions below.

Assumption 1

ℒn​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) is strongly convex with some (positive) parameter ΩnsubscriptΩ𝑛\Omega_{n}. That is, ℒn​(𝐲)≥ℒn​(𝐱)+(𝐲−𝐱)T​∇nℒn​(𝐱)+Ωn2​‖𝐲−𝐱‖2,∀𝐱,𝐲∈ℝdn,∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscriptℒ𝑛𝐲subscriptℒ𝑛𝐱superscript𝐲𝐱𝑇subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛𝐱subscriptΩ𝑛2superscriptnorm𝐲𝐱2for-all𝐱formulae-sequence𝐲superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑛for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{y})\geq\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{x})+(\bm{y}-\bm{x})^{T}\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{x})+\frac{\Omega_{n}}{2}\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\|^{2},\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{n}},\forall n\in[N].

Assumption 2

The gradient ∇nℒn​(⋅)subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) is Lipschitz continuous with some (positive) parameter L𝐿L. That is, ‖∇nℒn​(𝐱)−∇nℒn​(𝐲)‖≤Ln​‖𝐱−𝐲‖,∀𝐱,𝐲∈ℝdn,∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencenormsubscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛𝐱subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛𝐲subscript𝐿𝑛norm𝐱𝐲for-all𝐱formulae-sequence𝐲superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑛for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\|\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{x})-\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{y})\|\leq L_{n}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|,\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{n}},\forall n\in[N].

Assumption 3

ℒn​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) is twice-continuously differentiable, for ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N].

Assumption 4

The gradient with respect to any training sample, denoted by ∇nln​(𝛉n;⋅)subscript∇𝑛subscript𝑙𝑛subscript𝛉𝑛⋅\nabla_{n}l_{n}(\bm{\theta}_{n};\cdot), is upper bounded at 𝛉nsubscript𝛉𝑛\bm{\theta}_{n} as

‖∇nln​(𝜽n,𝒖n​m​k)‖2≤βn,1+βn,2​‖∇nℒn​(𝜽n)‖2,∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormsubscript∇𝑛subscript𝑙𝑛subscript𝜽𝑛subscript𝒖𝑛𝑚𝑘2subscript𝛽𝑛1subscript𝛽𝑛2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛subscript𝜽𝑛2for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\left\|\nabla_{n}l_{n}(\bm{\theta}_{n},\bm{u}_{nmk})\right\|^{2}\leq\beta_{n,1}+\beta_{n,2}\left\|\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\bm{\theta}_{n}\right)\right\|^{2},\forall n\in[N]

From Theorem 1, we see that ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)}) denotes the difference between the training loss and the optimal loss at t𝑡t-th round, which is upper bounded by the right side of the inequality in (1). In particular, ℒ​(𝜽(1))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))ℒsuperscript𝜽1ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)}) in this bound denotes the difference between the initialization loss and the optimal loss, and the second term of this bound is associated with the system error, including the sparsification error, the M-Turbo-CS estimation error, and the user selection error. We note that ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)}) converges with speed Υ(t)=maxn⁡Υn(t′)superscriptΥ𝑡subscript𝑛superscriptsubscriptΥ𝑛superscript𝑡′\Upsilon^{(t)}=\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n}^{(t^{\prime})} when Υ(t)<1superscriptΥ𝑡1\Upsilon^{(t)}<1. This condition holds when we choose Υn(t)<1superscriptsubscriptΥ𝑛𝑡1\Upsilon_{n}^{(t)}<1 for ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N] at each communication round t𝑡t. Empirically, we find that the proposed OA-FMTL scheme always converges with appropriately chosen system parameters. Moreover, we emphasize that the upper bound in (1) gives a performance metric of OA-FMTL and thus can be potentially used for system performance optimization. Due to space limitation, we leave more detailed discussions on system optimization to the extended version of this paper.

IV Experimental Results

In this section, we validate our proposed OA-FMTL scheme with experiments. Specifically, we consider federated image classification tasks on the MNIST and the Fashion-MNIST datasets, i.e., N=2𝑁2N=2, among M=20𝑀20M=20 local devices and an ES. For each task, we train a convolutional neural network with two convolution layers and two fully connected layers. Since user selection is not the focus of this paper, the channel gain {hm(t)}m=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡𝑚1𝑀\{h_{m}^{(t)}\}_{m=1}^{M} and the threshold ζ(t)superscript𝜁𝑡\zeta^{(t)} at each communication round defined in (14) are appropriately chosen to ensure that ℳ(t)superscriptℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}^{(t)} consists of M=20𝑀20M=20 devices during the whole training process. Besides, we set P=0.1,d1=d2=10920,k1=k2=0.1​d,γ(t)=1000,η=0.1formulae-sequenceformulae-sequence𝑃0.1subscript𝑑1subscript𝑑210920subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘20.1𝑑formulae-sequencesuperscript𝛾𝑡1000𝜂0.1P=0.1,d_{1}=d_{2}=10920,k_{1}=k_{2}=0.1d,\gamma^{(t)}=1000,\eta=0.1 for the following experiments. For comparison, we include the following two baseline schemes:

  • •

    Scheme I: Time division multiplexing (TDM) among the tasks is applied, i.e., each task is assigned with an orthogonal time slot to avoid inter-task interference. OA-FL [4] is applied in transmission, and Turbo-CS [10] is applied to recover the model aggregation at the ES.

  • •

    Scheme II: The proposed OA-FMTL framework is applied to jointly transmit the model parameters of all the tasks concurrently, and the Turbo-CS algorithm is used to individually recover the model aggregation of each task without considering the existence of inter-task interference.

Fig. 3 shows the numerical results of signal recovery at t=90𝑡90t=90 round. We see that the simulation results agree well with their corresponding evolution results, and that there is no state evolution result of Scheme II. Compared with Scheme II, we also notice that our proposed scheme performs better in overcoming inter-task interference. Besides, due to avoiding inter-task interference through TDM, Scheme I outperforms others in terms of converged MSE. However, subsequent experiment will show that the learning performance of our proposed scheme is comparable to that of Scheme I.

In Fig. 4, we measure the performance of each task in terms of test accuracy versus communication round t𝑡t. We observe that the test accuracy of our proposed scheme is close to that of Scheme I, and both schemes converge to an accuracy of 0.9 on the MNIST task as well as to an accuracy of 0.72 on the Fashion-MNIST task. We also note that the test accuracy of our proposed scheme is better than that of Scheme II, and is only about 2% lower than that of the ideal error-free bound, which demonstrates the excellent interference suppression capability of OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS.

For further comparison on the number of channel uses, we define ξnm​a​xsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥\xi_{n}^{max} as the maximum test accuracy of each task n𝑛n, and define t⋆​(ξ)superscript𝑡⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi) as the total required rounds of communications for every task n𝑛n to reach its target accuracy ξ⋅ξnm​a​x⋅𝜉superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥\xi\cdot\xi_{n}^{max}, where ξ𝜉\xi is called the relative target accuracy. Thus, t⋆​(ξ)superscript𝑡⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi) for Scheme II and our proposed scheme is given by

t⋆​(ξ)=m​a​x​{t1⋆​(ξ),…,tN⋆​(ξ)},superscript𝑡⋆𝜉𝑚𝑎𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑡1⋆𝜉…superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑁⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi)=max\{t_{1}^{\star}(\xi),\dots,t_{N}^{\star}(\xi)\}, (32)

where tn⋆​(ξ)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛⋆𝜉t_{n}^{\star}(\xi) is the required communication rounds of task n𝑛n to reach its target accuracy ξ⋅ξnm​a​x⋅𝜉superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛𝑚𝑎𝑥\xi\cdot\xi_{n}^{max}. Owing to the TDM technology, t⋆​(ξ)superscript𝑡⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi) of Scheme I is given by

t⋆​(ξ)=∑n=0Ntn⋆​(ξ).superscript𝑡⋆𝜉superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi)=\sum_{n=0}^{N}t_{n}^{\star}(\xi). (33)

Fig. 5 depicts the total required communication rounds t⋆superscript𝑡⋆t^{\star} versus relative target accuracy ξ𝜉\xi. We see that our proposed OA-FMTL scheme significantly outperforms the other two baseline schemes, and that the total required communication rounds of our proposed scheme to complete the N=2𝑁2N=2 tasks are only half of that of Scheme I at any value of ξ𝜉\xi. In addition, we note that Scheme II also requires fewer communication rounds than Scheme I, which demonstrates the advantage of non-orthogonal transmission.

V Conclusion

We developed an OA-FMTL framework with over-the-air computation to support multiple learning tasks over an non-orthogonal uplink channel. Furthermore, we modified the original Turbo-CS algorithm in the compressed sensing context to reconstruct the sparsified model aggregation updates at ES. Both the convergence analysis and experimental results showed that our proposed OA-FMTL framework is not sensitive to the inter-task interference, thereby achieving significant reduction in the total number of channel uses with only slight learning performance degradation.
